author: Anthony Nlebem
title: Paris 2024: Super Falcons fall to Brazil in Olympic opener
text: Nigeria’s Super Falcons suffered a narrow 1-0 defeat against Brazil in their opening Group C fixture at the 2024 Olympic Games on Thursday.

author: 观点地产网
title: 广州黄埔区生物医药3.0政策发布 全链条扶持生物医药产业|广州市_新浪财经_新浪网
text:
观点网讯： 近日，广州市黄埔区人民政府门户网站发布《广州开发区（黄埔区）促进生物医药产业高质量发展若干措施》（简称“生物医药3.0”政策），旨在全生命周期、全链条扶持生物医药产业，推动区域产业体系建设。
“生物医药3.0”政策共包含29条措施，覆盖加速科技创新突破、加快药械成果转化、优化临床服务配套、鼓励产品推广应用、加强产业生态培育、强化人才资源支撑等六个方面。政策重点支持创新药研发转化，对I、II、III期临床试验分别资助20%、30%、50%，其中III期临床资助比例全国最高。同时，政策推动创新药械应用和出海，对医疗机构用药目录新增创新药、采购创新产品给予补贴，对创新药进医保、仿制药中集采、创新药海外授权最高支持300万元。
此外，政策还打造产业生态和审批优势，引进培育龙头CRO企业，支持建设GLP平台和GMP中试平台等公共平台，提供全链条技术服务。针对细胞与基因治疗药物特点，单设支持条款，提高临床试验补贴额度，并支持生物制造，对生物原料药和生物药用辅料、“三新食品”给予资助。
政策的实施将为生物医药企业带来利好，进一步助推黄埔区“12136”现代化产业体系建设，全面推进生物医药产业发展。预计在“生物医药3.0”政策赋能下，生物岛企业将不断取得创新突破、加速成果转化，共同实现产业发展的新飞跃。
免责声明：本文内容与数据由观点根据公开信息整理，不构成投资建议，使用前请核实。
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->business strategy and marketing

author: Lissa Guyton
title: Rescue dogs in need of round-the-clock care helped through program at Toledo Correctional Institution
text: Planned Pethood has partnered with TOCI for a foster and training program TOLEDO, Ohio (WTVG) - Many rescue groups and shelters rely on foster homes when it comes to the animals in their care, but, there’s a shortage of fosters both here at home and across the country. One local rescue has an option for round-the-clock foster care, thanks to its partnership with a state prison. The program partners rescue dogs from Planned Pethood with inmates at the Toledo Correctional Institution. It’s helped find homes for dozens of dogs since it was started last year. The latest pups to be part of it were in need of 24/7 care, so this program was the perfect fit. It also helps open up foster homes for other dogs in need. Heidi and Hannah were brought to Planned Pethood by a Good Samaritan over the weekend. This week, the German Shepherds arrived at the Toledo Correctional Institution. “They are about a year old, but half the weight and size they should be. We believe they may be sisters,” Colleen Kane, a foster and volunteer with Planned Pethood said. The pictures and video in this story may not capture just how thin the two are. Teri Tomesek is a case manager at the prison and the coordinator of the program. She was shocked when she first saw the two. “They smelled, their ears were filthy, their skin is covered in scabs. They are severely underweight and clearly malnourished. They do not have a lot of muscle mass. There’s not much to them except skin and bones,” Tomesek said. Tomesek said in a matter of a few short days Heidi and Hannah have already started to show small signs of improvement both physically and mentally. “They’ve started to open up a bit. They are curious about other dogs, and they love to say hi to everybody coming down the hall,” Tomesek said. Because of their condition, the dogs are fed multiple times a day. Their handlers also get up throughout the night to check on them. “They are on a strict feeding schedule. They get about six meals a day so they are fed every few hours. We take the calorie intake of a dog the size they should be and we break it down to multiple meals a day so we don’t overwhelm their systems. Getting this skinny is a slow process and gaining the weight back is a slow process,” Tomesek said. “The handlers keep a log of everything. Things like when the dogs go to the bathroom, what they eat, how much they eat, what they are feeding them. Every morning they show me the log.” Kane said it’s amazing to see how dogs seem to live in the moment. “They are happy, sweet girls. All they want is love and attention. They have not met a stranger. This story shows the resiliency of dogs. In spite of what these girls have been through, they are happy to love in the end,” Kane said. “You’d think that after years of seeing dogs like this, you might not be shocked by what you see, but unfortunately, we are continually surprised by the condition of dogs we’ve been asked to help. There are so many resources in this community. If you need help, reach out. If we can’t help, we will try to connect you to an organization that can.” Because the prison can handle cases like this, Tomesek said it frees up other foster homes at a time when they’re already in short supply. “Our guys can do round-the-clock care, something a lot of other fosters can’t do because they have jobs, children and other obligations,” Tomesek said. Tomesek said it’s a program not only changing the course of the dogs lives, but the men caring for them. “It gives them a sense of purpose. It allows them to right some of their wrongs, to make some things right in the world. That is where the focus is and it’s amazing,” Tomesek said. Heidi and Hannah live with different handlers, but they spend time together throughout the day because the handlers work in the same place in the prison. Once the two are healthy, they will be up for adoption. If you’d like to help or learn more, click here . author: 网易
title: 我国开创二维金属研究新领域|材料|晶体管|低功耗_网易订阅
text: 据中国科学院物理研究所，该所科研团队近期成功研制出厚度仅为头发丝直径的二十万分之一的单原子层金属，这是国际上首次实现大面积二维金属材料的制备，开创了二维金属研究新领域。这种材料未来可以为超微型低功耗晶体管、透明显示等领域带来技术革新。该科研成果于北京时间3月13日在国际学术期刊《自然》发表。（央视新闻）

author: HANNAH HAYES
title: East Liverpool hospital reports spike in influenza A and RSV cases as flu admissions soar
text:
EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio — Officials at East Liverpool City Hospital are reporting a significant rise in Influenza A, as well as cases of RSV this season.
They say flu cases have increased drastically compared with last year, and RSV cases have risen from zero to five in that span.
"We’re seeing a very large uptick, especially in the last 2 weeks,” said Lisa Archer, RN, infection preventionist.
“We went from last year in February seeing about three influenza to this year seeing about 13 admitted patients with influenza."
Archer warned that people may be spreading these illnesses before they realize they are sick.
"Because, unfortunately, with these respiratory illnesses, you can be contagious for 1 to 2 days before you even know you have it," she said.
In addition to common cold-like symptoms, some flu patients are experiencing stomach issues.
"Runny nose, cough, congestion, fever we also been seeing some GI issues with this influenza. It’s kind of well-rounded, just like COVID was," Archer said.
With emergency rooms filling up, the hospital is encouraging patients with mild symptoms to seek care at clinics instead. Several options are available for those looking for a diagnosis without the long wait times of the ER.
"We also have some resident clinics in the hospital on the first floor, same day appointments, Wellsville Clinic same-day appointments,” Archer said. “We also have RVP that you can get same-day appointments. Those are great ways to avoid coming to the emergency room if you’re only looking for a diagnosis."
The recent influx of patients has put a strain on hospital resources with an unusually high number of admissions in a short period of time.
"We went all the way up to 15 influenza admissions in one week, and then we also had one day where we actually had 26 in just one day, which is abnormal for staff," Archer said.
According to the CDC, there have been at least 29 million flu cases nationwide this season, leading to 370,00 hospitalizations and 16,00 deaths.
"Wash your hands for 20 seconds,” Archer said. “Soap is not the only thing that is important, it is the friction, it is the amount of scrubbing you’re doing. You're scrubbing those germs off your hands."
The recommendation is to stay home, rest, and hydrate if symptoms are manageable. However, if more severe symptoms develop, like difficulty breathing or chest pain, you should seek medical care immediately.
